resource.chars:
if we consider yt in ye feilds a Man seldom or 
never receives more than one bite at a time, <u>wch <\u> 
doth infect him with so much Venom, as was 
instilled into ye man’s blood, when in these volun-
tary Experiments he suffer’d himself to be 
bitten twice together; & had likewise been 
bitten three times but a week or 10 
days before, some Remains of <u>wch <\u> Venom it is 
highly reasonable to imagin might still infect 
his blood at ye time he repeated the Experiments 
so as to make a fresh Quantity of ye Venom 
operate with greater violence upon his body 
than if he had been quite a fresh man never 
infected with ye like poison before, or at least 
at so great an interval of Time yt his 
blood might have been entirely free from 
all Remains of such an acrid Infection. 
From these experiments it: it not is reasonable to imagin that the 
oil by its self may be as efficacious against ye sting of a scor-
pion, as if <s>the <\s> Scorpions were infused in it.
<s>These experiments were repeated at Oxford 
& succeeded in much ye same manner only ye Man was 
not so bad; & experiments were made on seve-
rall other Animals, but especially a pidgeon 
One had Oil of Vipers applyed immediately, ye other 
the Remedy; ye first dyed, ye last never felt 
any violent symptom but continued well.
